title: Neuter Accusative (Same as Nominative).
reading_greek: Το παιδί βλέπει το δέντρο. Το δέντρο είναι μεγάλο. Βλέπω ένα ωραίο σπίτι. Το σπίτι είναι δίπλα στο δέντρο.
reading_english: The child sees the tree. The tree is big. I see a beautiful house. The house is next to the tree.
audio_script: Welcome to Week 11. Today, we're going to learn about a very helpful rule in Greek... the Neuter Accusative case is the same as the Neuter Nominative case. This means you don't have to change the ending of neuter nouns and adjectives when they are the direct object of a verb. Let's look at an example... Listen to this Greek text: "Το παιδί βλέπει το δέντρο. Το δέντρο είναι μεγάλο. Βλέπω ένα ωραίο σπίτι. Το σπίτι είναι δίπλα στο δέντρο." ... Now, let's break it down... In the first sentence, "Το παιδί βλέπει το δέντρο," 'το δέντρο' is the direct object, and it's in the neuter accusative, which looks identical to the neuter nominative. The same applies to 'το σπίτι' in the last sentence. Remember, for neuter words, the nominative and accusative forms are the same! Keep practicing, and you'll master this in no time.
